Semua anak tak ke sekolah
01 Nov 2019, 06:30 by Nurul Fatihah Sulaini
“MA bakpo saya tak boleh sekolah.” Luahan sayu Mohd Azam Abdul Aziz, sembilan tahun itu sering diajukan kepada ibunya, Siti Aishah Aziz, 39, setiap kali melihat rakan sebayanya menggalas beg ke sekolah.
Siti Aishah berkata, dia hanya mampu meminta anaknya bersabar dan berusaha memujuk dengan harapan satu hari nanti Mohd Azam berpeluang menjejakkan kaki ke sekolah.
Katanya, enam daripada tujuh anaknya berusia lingkungan enam bulan hingga 16 tahun tidak mempunyai sijil kelahiran kerana dokumen sijil nikahnya bersama suami hilang yang menyukarkan proses membuat pendaftaran kelahiran.
“Hanya anak sulung, Mohd Azwan yang ada sijil kelahiran, tetapi maklumat bapa tiada menyebabkan proses daftar sekolah tidak boleh dilakukan. Dia seorang saja sempat ke tadika...yang lain langsung tidak pernah ke sekolah,” katanya.
Lebih menimbulkan kesulitan, suaminya, Abdul Aziz Yaacob, 57, baru sahaja meninggal dunia 1 Oktober lalu akibat penyakit strok dan jantung.


MENUNJUKKAN buku rekod kelahiran anak-anaknya di Hospital Besut Terengganu di rumahnya Kampung Kelubi Putih, Jabi. FOTO Nurul Fatihah Sulaini

Siti Aishah yang juga warga Thailand ketika ditemui di rumahnya di Kampung Kelubi Putih, Jabi di sini berkata, dia berkahwin dengan suaminya yang berasal dari sini, di sempadan Thailand pada 2001 ketika berusia 21 tahun.
“Namun perkahwinan kami tidak didaftarkan secara rasmi di negara ini dan lebih merumitkan keadaan, sijil nikah itu hilang daripada simpanan.
“Saya bimbang memikirkan masa depan anak selain tidak boleh ke sekolah, kami perlu membayar caj rawatan lebih mahal di klinik dan hospital kerajaan.
“Apabila mereka mahu berkahwin kelak, proses untuk mendaftar perkahwinan juga lebih sukar kerana tiada rekod maklumat peribadi,” katanya.
Dia berkata, disebabkan tidak boleh bersekolah, tiga anak lelakinya berumur 16, 15 dan 12 tahun memilih untuk bekerja pada usia muda.
“Anak sulung dan ketiga bekerja sebagai pembantu kedai. Seawal jam 7.30 pagi keluar rumah dan pulang jam 6 petang. Anak kedua pula makan gaji membuat kerja pendawaian elektrik. Walaupun mereka masih muda tapi rajin bekerja.
“Saya berharap ada pihak seperti Jabatan Pendaftaran Negara (JPN) dan Jabatan Pendidikan boleh membantu kami sekeluarga untuk mendapatkan sijil kelahiran bagi memudahkan anak saya bersekolah satu hari nanti,” katanya.

All the kids didn't go to school
01 Nov 2019, 06:30 by Nurul Fatihah Sulaini
“My dad can't go to school.” Mohd Azam Abdul Aziz's nine-year-old daughter often asked her mother, Siti Aishah Aziz, 39, every time she saw her partner go to school.
Siti Aishah said she was only able to ask her son to be patient and to try to persuade him that one day Mohd Azam would have the opportunity to walk to school.
She said six out of seven children between the ages of six and 16 had no birth certificates because her marriage certificate with the missing husband made it difficult to process birth registration.
“Only the eldest son, Mohd Azwan, has a birth certificate, but the father's information does not make the school registration process impossible. He was the only person to attend kindergarten ... the others never went to school, "he said.
Worse yet, her husband, Abdul Aziz Yaacob, 57, had just passed away on October 1 due to stroke and heart disease.


Presenting her birth record book at Terengganu Besut Hospital in her hometown of Kampung Kelubi White, Jabi. PHOTO Nurul Fatihah Sulaini

Siti Aishah, who is also a Thai when met at her home in Kampung Kelubi White, Jabi here, said she married her husband from here, on the Thai border in 2001 when she was 21 years old.
“However, our marriage is not officially registered in the country and to complicate matters, the marriage certificate is out of stock.
"I'm worried about the future of our children and not being able to go to school, we have to pay more expensive treatment costs at government clinics and hospitals.
"When they want to get married later, the process of registering a marriage is also more difficult as there is no record of personal information," he said.
She said that because she couldn't go to school, her three boys, ages 16, 15, and 12 chose to work at a young age.
“The eldest and the third worked as a shop assistant. As early as 7.30am left the house and returned at 6pm. The second child earns a living doing electrical wiring work. Although they are young but work hard.
"I hope someone like the National Registration Department (NRD) and the Education Department can help our family obtain a birth certificate to make it easier for my child to attend school one day," he said.
